definition: essential organic compounds that the body needs in small amounts for various metabolic processes and to maintain overall health
notes: vital for growth, development, and proper bodily function
since the body cannot produce most vitamins, they must be obtained through diet
warnings: excessive intake of certain vitamins can be harmful

definition: inorganic elements present in soil and water, which are absorbed by plants or consumed by animals
notes: some diuretics commonly prescribed to lower blood pressure can deplete the body’s stores of magnesium, potassium, and calcium

content.name: fat-soluble
notes: stored in the liver and fatty tissues
be very careful about taking large amounts of fat-soluble vitamin supplements as these can build up in your body and may cause harmful effects

content.name: water-soluble
notes: not stored in the body for long periods

definition: The average daily level of intake that is enough to meet the nutrient needs of nearly all (97% to 98%) healthy people. An RDA is an intake level based on scientific research evidence.
This level is established when there is not enough scientific research evidence to develop an RDA. It is set at a level that is thought to ensure enough nutrition.

name: choline
use: normal functioning of the brain and nervous system
used to synthesize acetylcholine, a neurotransmitter involved in muscle control and numerous functions of the nervous system
involved in early development of the brain, gene expression, cell membrane signaling, and brain metabolism
notes: lack of choline can cause swelling in the liver
although humans synthesize choline in the liver, the amount produced naturally is insufficient to meet cellular functions
a structural component of phospholipids and cell membranes
present in breast milk and is commonly added as an ingredient to baby foods
not formally classified as a vitamin despite being an essential nutrient with an amino acid–like structure and metabolism
stored in the cell membranes and organelles as phospholipids, and inside cells as phosphatidylcholines and glycerophosphocholines
wikipedia recommends 425 mg for women, 550 mg for men, per day

name: carnitine
use: helps the body to change fatty acids into energy
heart and brain function
Swelling (inflammation) of the heart (myocarditis)
muscle movement
many other body processes
notes: made in the human brain, liver, and kidneys
derived from an amino acid
the generic term for several compounds, including L-carnitine, acetyl-L-carnitine, and propionyl-L-carnitine
naturally present in many foods—especially animal origin
dietary carnitine has a bioavailability of about 63% to 75%
available as a dietary supplement
increases sperm count and sperm movement in males with fertility problems

name: retinol
food-sources: oily fish – such as salmon, sardines, trout, herring or mackerel
use: helps form and maintain healthy teeth, bones, soft tissue, mucous membranes, and skin
helping your body's natural defence against illness and infection (the immune system) work properly
helping vision in dim light
keeping skin and the lining of some parts of the body, such as the nose, healthy
notes: you can also get vitamin A by including good sources of beta-carotene in your diet, as the body can convert this into retinol

some research suggests that having more than an average of 1.5 mg (1,500 µg) a day of vitamin A over many years may affect your bones, making them more likely to fracture when you're older. This is particularly important for older people, especially women, who are already at increased risk of osteoporosis, a condition that weakens bones.

name: beta-carotene
food-sources: yellow, red and green (leafy) vegetables, such as spinach, carrots, sweet potatoes and red peppers
yellow fruit, such as mango, papaya and apricots

name: thiamine
use: helps the body cells change carbohydrates into energy: getting enough carbohydrates is very important during pregnancy and breastfeeding
essential for heart function and healthy nerve cells

name: riboflavin
use: works with the other B vitamins
important for body growth
important for the production of red blood cells

name: niacin
use: helps maintain healthy skin and nerves
has triglyceride-lowering effects at higher doses

name: pantothenic acid
use: essential for the metabolism of food
plays a role in the production of hormones and cholesterol

name: pyridoxine
use: helps form red blood cells and maintain brain function
plays an important role in the proteins that are part of many chemical reactions in the body
notes: milling and processing (of grains) emoves a lot of B6

name: biotin
use: essential for the metabolism of proteins and carbohydrates
essential for the production of hormones and cholesterol

name: folate
use: works with vitamin B12 to help form red blood cells
needed for the production of DNA, which controls tissue growth and cell function
many foods are now fortified with folate in the form of folic acid
food-sources: dried beans (cooked pinto, navy, kidney, and lima)
notes: any woman who is pregnant should be sure to get enough folate; low levels of folate are linked to birth defects such as spina bifida and anencephaly. For the folate to be effective, it must be taken in the first few weeks of conception, often before a woman knows she is pregnant. Yet in the U.S., half of all pregnancies are unplanned. That’s why the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommend that all women of childbearing age (ages 15 to 45) consume 600 micrograms a day of folic acid.

name: B12
use: helps form red blood cells
helps maintain the central and peripheral nervous systems
important for metabolism
notes: some people over age 50 have trouble absorbing the vitamin B12 found naturally in foods
animal sources of vitamin B12 are absorbed much better by the body than plant sources
the National Academy of Medicine, in fact, recommends that people over the age of 50 eat foods fortified with vitamin B12 or take vitamin B12 pills that are better absorbed than from food sources

name: ascorbic acid
use: antioxidant
promotes healthy teeth and gums
helps the body absorb iron
helps maintain healthy tissue
essential for wound healing
notes: smokers should add 35 milligrams

name: calciferol
notes: also known as the "sunshine vitamin," since it is made by the body after being in the sun. Ten to 15 minutes of sunshine 3 times a week is enough to produce the body's requirement for most people at most latitudes. People who do not live in sunny places may not make enough vitamin D
It is very hard to get enough vitamin D from food sources alone

title: Getting enough D
text: For most people, the best way to get enough vitamin D is taking a supplement because it is hard to get enough through food. Although some foods are fortified with vitamin D, few foods contain it naturally. Vitamin D supplements are available in two forms: vitamin D2 ("ergocalciferol" or pre-vitamin D) and vitamin D3 ("cholecalciferol"). Both are also naturally occurring forms that are produced in the presence of the sun’s ultraviolet-B (UVB) rays, but D2 is produced in plants and fungi and D3 in animals, including humans. Vitamin D production in the skin is the primary natural source of vitamin D, but many people have insufficient levels because they live in places where sunlight is limited in winter, or because they have limited sun exposure. Also, people with darker skin tend to have lower blood levels of vitamin D because the pigment (melanin) acts like a shade, reducing production of vitamin D.

name: alpha-tocopherol
uses: helps the body form red blood cells
helps the bod use vitamin K
food-sources: margarine (made from safflower, corn, and sunflower oil)
wheat germ and wheat germ oil

use: essential for blood to coagulate normally
some studies suggest that it is important for bone health

name: iron
use: for making red blood cells, which carry oxygen around the body
food-sources: beans, such as red kidney beans, edamame beans and chickpeas
dried fruit, such as dried apricots
notes: a lack of iron can lead to iron deficiency anaemia
non-menstruating women need only take 9 mg per day

name: calcium
notes: good for strong bones and teeth

name: chloride
notes: good for strong bones and teeth

name: magnesium
use: turn the food we eat into energy
make sure the parathyroid glands, which produce hormones important for bone health, work normally
notes: taking high doses of magnesium (more than 400mg) for a short time can cause diarrhoea
Harvard recommends 320 mg for women, 420 mg for men

name: manganese
use: helps make and activate some of the enzymes in the body
notes: For most people, taking 4mg or less of manganese supplements a day is unlikely to cause any harm. For older people, who may be more sensitive to manganese, taking 0.5mg or less of manganese supplements a day is unlikely to cause any harm.

name: molibdenum
uses: helps make and activate some of the proteins involved in chemical reactions (enzymes) that help with repairing and making genetic material
notes: foods that grow above ground tend to be higher in molybdenum than foods that grow below the ground, such as potatoes or carrots
some evidence to suggest taking molybdenum supplements might cause joint pain

name: phosphorus
use: helps build strong bones and teeth
helps release energy from food

overdose.effects: reduce the amount of calcium in the body, which means bones are more likely to fracture

notes: taking 250mg or less a day of phosphorus supplements on top of the phosphorous you get from your diet is unlikely to cause any harm
Harvard recommends 700 mg / day

name: potassium
use: helps control the balance of fluids in the body
helps the heart muscle work properly
food-sources: some vegetables (such as broccoli, parsnips and brussels sprouts)
notes: Harvard recommends [2600,3400] mg DV, that is much less for women

name: sodium
notes: Men 51 and older should reduce their sodium intake to 2,300 mg each day. That is about 1 teaspoon of salt and includes sodium added during manufacturing or cooking as well as at the table when eating. If you have high blood pressure or prehypertension, limiting sodium intake to 1,500 mg per day, about 2/3 teaspoon of salt, may be helpful.
Harvard recommends [1500,1500] mg DV

name: iodine
use: helps make thyroid hormones, which help keep cells and the metabolic rate (the speed at which chemical reactions take place in the body) healthy
iodine can also be found in plant foods, such as cereals and grains, but the levels vary depending on the amount of iodine in the soil where the plants are grown
notes: Taking high doses of iodine for long periods of time could change the way your thyroid gland works. This can lead to a wide range of different symptoms, such as weight gain.

name: fluoride
use: help dental health by strengthening the tooth enamel, making it more resistant to tooth decay
reduces the amount of acid that the bacteria on your teeth produce
notes: found in all drinking water, yet the amount varies from area to area
the addition of fluoride to water has been researched for over 60 years, and water fluoridation has been proven to reduce tooth decay by 40 to 60 percent
having 0.7 to 1.2 parts of fluoride for every million parts of water (0.7ppm to 1.2ppm) has been shown to have the best effect
some countries add fluoride to their table salt and milk instead of to the water supplies
children who have fluoride when their teeth are developing tend to have shallower grooves in their teeth, so plaque can be more easily removed

one cup of tea can contain between 0.3 milligrams and 0.5 milligrams of fluoride, and if you drink it with milk your teeth will also benefit from the calcium. It is best to drink tea without sugar to reduce the risk of tooth decay even more

name: zinc
use: making new cells and enzymes
processing carbohydrate, fat and protein in food
wound healing
overdose: reduces the amount of copper the body can absorb, which can lead to anaemia and weakening of the bones
notes: Harvard recommends [3,11] mg DV

name: copper
notes: Taking high doses of copper could cause: stomach pain, sickness, diarrhoea, damage to the liver and kidneys (if taken for a long time)
recommended daily intake ranges between 900 and 1100 ug

name: selenium
use: helps the immune system work properl
in reproduction
helps prevent damage to cells and tissues
overdose: selenosis, a condition that, in its mildest form, can lead to loss of hair and nails
notes: Taking high doses of copper could cause: stomach pain, sickness, diarrhoea, damage to the liver and kidneys (if taken for a long time)
Harvar recommend [55,55] ug DV
